questions.text: Which of the following was the world’s first international health agency?

choices.text: Health Organization of the League of Nations
United States Agency for International Development

questions.solution:
The first international health agency to be established was the Pan American Sanitary Bureau (PASB) in 1902. 

This was followed by the establishment of the Health Organization of the League of Nations in 1923.

The World Health Organisation (WHO) was established on 7th April 1948.

questions.text: When is breastfeeding week celebrated?
questions.solution:
Breastfeeding week is celebrated in the 1st week of August.

questions.text: What was the theme for World Health Day 2023?
questions.solution:
The theme for World Health Day 2023 was Health for all. 

World Health Day is celebrated on 7th April and each year a different theme is adopted such as:

  • 2024- My health, my right
  • 2022- Our planet, our health
  • 2021- Build a fairer, healthier world for everyone, everywhere
  • 2020 - Support nurses and midwives
  • 2018 & 2019 - Universal health coverage: everyone, everywhere
  • 2017 - Depression: Let’s talk
  • 2016 - Beat diabetes
  • 2015 - Food safety

World Health Day on April 7th raises awareness about global health issues. The 2024 theme, "My health, my right" highlights access to quality healthcare as a fundamental human right. This year's focus is on ensuring universal access to healthcare for all.

questions.text: When is World No Tobacco Day observed?
questions.solution:
World No Tobacco Day is observed on 31st May.

The theme of World No Tobacco Day 2021 is 'commit to quit'. It conveys that the COVID-19 pandemic has led to millions of tobacco users saying they want to quit.

The theme of World No Tobacco Day 2020 was #TobaccoExposed. It aimed to provide a counter-marketing campaign that shows smokers have a higher risk of getting a severe case of COVID-19 and to empower young people to engage in the fight against tobacco.

questions.text: What was the theme of World TB Day 2023?

choices.text: Invest to End TB. Save Lives

questions.solution:
The theme of world TB day 2023 was 'Yes! We can end TB!'.

World Tuberculosis Day is observed on 24th March of every year.

The themes for the other world TB days are:

The theme of 2024 continues to be, 'Yes! We can end TB!'

2022: Invest to End TB. Save Lives

2021: The clock is ticking

2020: It's time to End TB

2019: It’s time for action

2018: Wanted: Leaders for a TB-free world

questions.text: Where is the headquarters of the WHO located?
questions.solution:
The headquarters of the WHO is in Geneva, Switzerland.

The WHO is a specialized, non-political health agency of the United Nations. It came into force on 7th April 1948.

Its objective is the attainment of the highest level of health by all people. The structure of the WHO includes:

  • The World Health Assembly
  • The Executive Board
  • The Secretariat

Important headquarters of international organisations include:

  • The headquarters of UNICEF and UNDP is in New York, USA.
  • Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) headquarters is in Rome, Italy.
  • Headquarters of the International Labor Organization (ILO) and the International Red Cross are also in Geneva.   

The image below shows the WHO emblem.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the duties of the WHO?
questions.solution:
State health is not one of the duties of the WHO. It is the responsibility of the government.

Work and duties of the WHO:

  • Prevention and control of specific diseases
  • Development of comprehensive health services
  • Family health
  • Environmental health
  • Health statistics
  • Biomedical research
  • Health literature and information
  • Cooperation with other organizations

questions.text: Where is the South East Asian Regional Office of the WHO located?
questions.solution:
The South-East Asian Regional Office (SEARO) of the WHO is located in New Delhi. Duties of the SEARO include planning for malaria eradication, tuberculosis control, and rural health services.

Members of SEARO are: 

  • Bangladesh
  • India
  • Bhutan
  • Indonesia
  • Democratic People’s Republic of Korea
  • The Republic of Maldives
  • Myanmar
  • Nepal
  • Sri Lanka
  • Thailand
  • Timor-Leste

The regional offices of the WHO are listed below.

Regional office Location
South-East Asian office New Delhi, India
African regional office Brazzaville, Republic of Congo
American regional office Washington D. C., USA
European regional head office Copenhagen, Denmark
Eastern Mediterranean office Alexandria, Egypt
Western Pacific regional office Manila, Philippines

questions.text: What is the surveillance reporting system used by the WHO?
questions.solution:
The surveillance reporting system used by the WHO is the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

The WHO collects and disseminates epidemiological information on diseases subject to International Health Regulations. It is done through an Automatic Telex Reply Service (ATRS) and the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

questions.text: As a part of the ‘Clean care is safer care’ campaign, you have been asked to give a presentation to the nurses in the obstetrics and gynecology department. Which of the following areas is targeted in this campaign?
questions.solution:
‘Clean care is safer care’ campaign was started by the WHO to improve hand hygiene practices. 

In 2005, WHO developed this campaign aimed at the reduction of healthcare-associated infections (HCAI) through the worldwide promotion of appropriate hand hygiene practices.

questions.text: Which agency of the United Nations has the given logo?
questions.solution:
The given logo is that of the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF). It works closely with the WHO on health matters.

UNICEF’s content of services include:

  • Child health
  • Child nutrition
  • Family and child welfare
  • Formal and informal education

UNICEF participates in urban basic services (UBS) with the aim to promote access to basic services like nutrition, water supply, and sanitation. 

UNICEF started the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) to promote breastfeeding and improve maternal and child care. In 2016, the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare launched the Mothers Absolute Affection (MAA) programme to revitalize efforts towards protection, promotion and support of breastfeeding practices.

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of UNICEF’s GOBI FFF strategy?
  1. Growth monitoring with growth charts
  2. Oral hygiene
  3. Family planning and birth spacing
  4. Food fortification
  5. Female literacy promotion
questions.solution:
The components of the GOBI FFF strategy by the UNICEF are:

  • Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • Breastfeeding
  • Immunization of children
  • Family planning and birth spacing
  • Food supplementation
  • Female literacy promotion

The GOBI FFF strategy is aimed at revolutionising child health and survival. Initially, it was called GOBI strategy and later the FFF aspect was added to it.  

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: Which agency of the UN gives funds for technical assistance and has the following as part of its logo?
questions.solution:
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) is an agency of the UN that gives funds for technical assistance. It has the following logo.  

Its main objective is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources to their potential. 

Some other agencies of the UN include:

  • UNESCO - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
  • UNEP - United Nations Environment Programme
  • UNHCR - United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees 

Their logos are given below.

questions.text: Which organisation gives the highest funding for reproductive health?
questions.solution:
United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) gives the highest funding for reproductive health. It works in the area of health and family welfare. 

It mainly works by:

  • Developing the national capability in manufacturing contraceptives,
  • Promoting population education programmes
  • Introducing innovative approaches to family planning and MCH care.

Sexual and Reproductive Health Awareness Day is organized on February 12th every year to raise awareness about sexual and reproductive health.  

The logo of the UNFPA is given below.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an objective of the FAO?

choices.text: To better the condition of rural people
Improve nutrition of people of all countries

questions.solution:
Improving access to nutritious foods is not one of the objectives of the FAO. 

Aims of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO):

  • To help nations raise living standards
  • To improve the nutrition of people of all countries
  • To increase the efficiency of farming, forestry, and fisheries
  • To better the condition of rural people

The FAO organized a Freedom from Hunger Campaign (FFHC) in 1960. Its main objective was to combat malnutrition and to disseminate information and education. 

The FAO logo is given below.

questions.text: Which agency of the United Nations has the following logo?

choices.text: United States Agency for International Development

questions.solution:
The given logo is of the World Bank.

It helps less developed countries raise their living standards with economic support. The allocation of funds is decided by its Board of Governors.

questions.text: What does the branch of medicine known as nosology deal with?
questions.solution: Nosology is the branch of medicine that deals with the classification of diseases.

questions.text: Study of which of the following is known as emporiatrics?
questions.solution:
Emporiatrics is the study of the health of travelers.

It is also called travel medicine. It deals with the prevention and management of health problems of international travelers.

questions.text: Quarantine measures were implemented for the first time to prevent the spread of:
questions.solution:
Quarantine was introduced for the first time to prevent the spread of the plague, also known as the black death. 

Quarantine is the restriction on the movement of people, animals, and goods that may have been exposed to a communicable disease. It is intended to prevent the spread of communicable diseases. 

Quarantine is distinct from medical isolation, in which those confirmed to be infected with a communicable disease are isolated from the healthy population.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Disease (TDR) strategy of the WHO?
questions.solution:
Tick-borne encephalitis is not included in the Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Disease (TDR) strategy of the WHO. The diseases included under this programme are:

  • Chagas disease
  • Dengue
  • Ebola
  • Helminthiasis
  • Leishmaniasis
  • Leprosy
  • Lymphatic filariasis
  • Malaria
  • Onchocerciasis
  • Schistosomiasis
  • Trypanosomiasis
  • Tuberculosis

The programme is sponsored by the WHO, UNICEF, UNDP, and World Bank.

World Neglected Tropical Diseases Day is observed on 30th January, with the 2025 theme Unite. Act. Eliminate. This year, WHO highlights the need for bold and sustainable investments to break the cycle of disease and poverty affecting 1.5 billion vulnerable people. The focus is on strengthening commitment, mobilizing resources, delivering treatment, reducing transmission, managing disabilities, and tackling the stigma surrounding NTDs.

questions.text: According to the International Health Regulations, on diagnosing a patient with which of the following diseases is notification not mandatory in all countries?
questions.solution:
According to the International Health Regulations(IHR), notification is not mandatory if a patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis in all countries.

It needs to be notified only by the countries where the public health impact is serious and there is a risk of international spread.

The government of India made the reporting of new cases of TB mandatory for all medical practitioners from 2012. An online web-based application named Nikshay is available for this purpose. Treatment providers are given a nominal cash incentive of Rs.1000/- per TB patient reported.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is not under international surveillance by the WHO?
questions.solution:
Chagas disease is not under international surveillance by the WHO. 

Surveillance is usually done for infectious diseases and diseases that have the potential to become epidemics or pandemics.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following diseases do not require isolation or quarantine?
questions.solution:
Patients with West Nile fever do not require isolation or quarantine.

Isolation and quarantine are used for highly infectious diseases that are at risk of becoming epidemics or pandemics.

questions.text: You are asked to investigate a possible act of terrorism using anthrax. Which of the following is false regarding this category of bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Anthrax falls under category A of bioterrorism agents. These organisms are usually easy to disseminate.

Category A refers to high priority agents. They have high case-fatality rates and high transmissibility. Thus, a specialised public health response is required to combat such attacks.

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples
Category A

High priority agents

Easily disseminated

High mortality rate

Capacity to get disseminated

Social disruption

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Clostridium botulinum

Yersinia pestis

Variola major

Francisella tularensis

Ebola and other hemorrhagic fevers

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

 
Category B 

Minority priority agents

Moderately well disseminated

Moderate morbidity and low mortality

Require enhancement of CD and diagnostic capacity

Coxiella burnetti

Burkholderia mallei

Burkholderia pseudomallei

Ricin toxin

Cryptosporidium parvum

Salmonella typhi

Chlamydia psittaci
Category C

Low priority agents

Could be engineered for mass dissemination

Readily available

Easy to produce

Potentially high morbidity and mortality

 Emergent viruses -Nipah and Hantavirus

questions.text: How many goals does the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) comprise of?
questions.solution:
The Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) are comprised of 17 goals.

These were set as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030.  These goals consist of a total of 169 targets. SDGs replaced the Millennium Development Goals on 1st January 2016. 

The 2030 agenda consists of five P's: 

  • People
  • Planet
  • Prosperity
  • Peace
  • Partnership
